articles.headline: Like American, More Airlines Add Fees for Checking Luggage
articles.snippet: United and US Airways joined American Airlines in assessing a $15 luggage fee for passengers flying on the cheapest tickets.
articles.abstract: United and US Airways joined American Airlines in assessing a $15 luggage fee for passengers flying on the cheapest tickets.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, American Airlines stood alone in facing the ire of passengers over its decision to begin charging $15 to check the first bag. But it now has some company.

articles.headline: Deafening Howl, Then Deadly Chaos for Scouts
articles.snippet: Four died when a tornado hit a Boy Scout camp in Iowa, destroying the building around a troop and injuring 48.
articles.abstract: Four died when a tornado hit a Boy Scout camp in Iowa, destroying the building around a troop and injuring 48.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLENCOE, Iowa  Just before the tornado hit, the Boy Scouts were gathering on the porch of a shelter, playing cards and waiting out what many of them thought was just a pelting rain. In a matter of moments, a scout leader, hearing a faint tornado siren, hurried them inside, and then, as he stared out the open door and saw the twister in the distance, ordered them to dive under tables, survivors said.
articles.byline: By Catrin Einhorn and Monica Davey

articles.headline: A Bull Market Sees the Worst in Speculators
articles.snippet: Hostility in Washington toward speculators is starting to worry people who know how commodity markets work.
articles.abstract: Hostility in Washington toward speculators is starting to worry people who know how commodity markets work.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Washington, financial speculators have fat targets on their backs.

articles.headline: Retail Sales Rise Above Forecasts
articles.snippet: Sales of retail goods and services rose 1 percent in May, double what economists had expected, the Commerce Department said.
articles.abstract: Sales of retail goods and services rose 1 percent in May, double what economists had expected, the Commerce Department said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retail sales picked up last month as Americans received more than $50 billion in stimulus checks. Investors took the report as an encouraging sign for the resilience of the economy, even as some analysts wondered how long the uptick would last.

articles.headline: Japan, Seeking Trim Waists, Measures Millions
articles.snippet: A country not known for obesity has undertaken an ambitious campaign to slim down its citizenry.
articles.abstract: A country not known for obesity has undertaken an ambitious campaign to slim down its citizenry.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMAGASAKI, Japan  Japan, a country not known for its overweight people, has undertaken one of the most ambitious campaigns ever by a nation to slim down its citizenry.

articles.headline: Good Times Left Lehman Unprepared for the Bad
articles.snippet: Sometimes, when you really mess up, it is good to admit you erred. Unfortunately, no one seems to have gotten that message through to Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: Sometimes, when you really mess up, it is good to admit you erred. Unfortunately, no one seems to have gotten that message through to Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, when you really mess up, it is good to admit you erred.

articles.headline: In California, a House Divided Stands Strong
articles.snippet: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is supporting Senator John McCain, while his wife, Maria Shriver, is backing Senator Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is supporting Senator John McCain, while his wife, Maria Shriver, is backing Senator Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  It is one thing to disagree about politics with your spouse at a backyard barbecue. It is quite another to do it in front of the 38 million people of California, with apparent and abundant passion.

articles.headline: In Lehman Fallout, Two Stars Are Given Lesser Roles
articles.snippet: The struggling investment bank said that two top executives had been removed a few days after it reported a $2.8 billion quarterly loss.
articles.abstract: The struggling investment bank said that two top executives had been removed a few days after it reported a $2.8 billion quarterly loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 10 nightmarish days inside the headquarters of Lehman Brothers, nerves on the 31st floor continued to fray. By Wednesday evening, the president and chief financial officer were out  a dramatic attempt by Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehman’s pugnacious chief executive, to restore confidence in his beleaguered bank and safeguard his own job.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Ad Accord for Yahoo and Google
articles.snippet: In a deal aimed at lifting Yahoo’s finances, Google agreed to deliver ads next to some of Yahoo’s search results.
articles.abstract: In a deal aimed at lifting Yahoo’s finances, Google agreed to deliver ads next to some of Yahoo’s search results.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft’s four-month-long courtship of Yahoo has finally thrown Yahoo into the arms of their biggest common rival, Google.

articles.headline: Media Charged With Sexism in Clinton Coverage
articles.snippet: Many in the news media see little need to reconsider their coverage of the Clinton campaign.
articles.abstract: Many in the news media see little need to reconsider their coverage of the Clinton campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angered by what they consider sexist news coverage of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, many women and erstwhile Clinton supporters are proposing boycotts of the cable networks, putting up videos on a “Media Hall of Shame,” starting a national conversation about sexism and pushing Mrs. Clinton’s rival, Senator Barack Obama, to address the matter.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Julie Bosman
